Hi all,

I came across a paper which might be relevant to novelty search an=
d other
methods to reduce or change selection pressure:
http://www.lel.ed.a=
c.uk/~simon/Papers/Ritchie/Selection,%20domestication,%20and%20the%20emerge=
nce%20of%20learned%20communication.pdf

There's a kind of bird (a white-bac=
ked munia) which has a fairly simple
song, and a domesticated variant of it=
 which has apparently evolved over
just a couple of hundred years (of domes=
tication) to produce much more
complex songs. The domesticated birds can le=
arn the songs of the wild birds
but the wild birds are often unable to lear=
n the songs of the domesticated
bird, so it seems to be due to a physiologi=
cal difference.

In the paper they hypothesise that this increase in song c=
omplexity can be
accounted for by the removal of selection pressure in the =
domesticated
population, allowing more genetic drift. They use a simulation=
 of evolution
to lend weight to their argument. The birds in a new generati=
on learn from
song samples, selected according to a genetically encoded fil=
ter, of the
birds in the previous generation. The simulation starts out wit=
h birds
which only produce simple songs and whose fitness is determined by =
their
ability to recognise using their own filter, and be recognised by acc=
ording
to the filters of other birds, their own species via the songs they =
sing.
While this selection pressure is in place the songs remain simple.
Se=
lection pressure is completely removed part way through evolution and an
in=
crease in song complexity is then observed.

The simulation seems a little =
contrived and simplistic, but I'm not sure
how much this affects the interp=
retation of the result. It perhaps provides
an interesting example of how s=
trong selection pressure can constrain
evolution to a "corner" of the searc=
h space, in this case the corner of
simple songs: pressure to recognise, an=
d be recognised by, other members of
the same species is best met by produc=
ing simple songs. Although in this
case evolution is producing individuals =
that are "fit" in the context of
the fitness function, it doesn't appear to=
 be getting stuck in local
optima; the point isn't to improve the performan=
ce of the evolved
individuals according to some metric that doesn't influen=
ce evolution (=E0 la
novelty search).

One potentially significant aspect t=
hat their simulation doesn't explain or
attempt to model is that the domest=
icated birds can learn more complex
songs than their wild counterparts (onl=
y the filter for selecting songs to
learn from and recognising other member=
s of the same species is genetically
encoded).

Cheers,
Oliver
